G.L. c. 218, \u00a7\u00a7 19, 19A and 21.proposition: Jurisdiction is proper in this Court pursuant to G.L. c. 218, §§ 19, 19A and 21, and G.L. c. 212, § 4, as the Defendant does business in this Commonwealth and the causes of action arose within this Commonwealth.

G.L. c. 212, \u00a7 4.proposition: Jurisdiction is proper in this Court pursuant to G.L. c. 218, §§ 19, 19A and 21, and G.L. c. 212, § 4, as the Defendant does business in this Commonwealth and the causes of action arose within this Commonwealth.

G.L. c. 223, \u00a7\u00a7 1, 2.proposition: Venue is proper in the Somerville District Court pursuant to G.L. c. 223, §§ 1, 2 and G.L. c. 223A, § 3, because the events giving rise to this action occurred in Somerville, Middlesex County, Massachusetts, within the territorial jurisdiction of this Court.

G.L. c. 223A, \u00a7 3.proposition: Venue is proper in the Somerville District Court pursuant to G.L. c. 223, §§ 1, 2 and G.L. c. 223A, § 3, because the events giving rise to this action occurred in Somerville, Middlesex County, Massachusetts, within the territorial jurisdiction of this Court.

Mounsey v. Ellard, 363 Mass. 693, 707 (1.proposition: At all times relevant, Plaintiff was a business invitee to whom Defendant owed a duty of reasonable care in the ownership, operation, inspection, maintenance, and control of the Premises, including the aisles, floors, and walking surfaces of the store.  See Mounsey v. Ellard, 363 Mass. 693, 707 (1973) (landowners owe lawful visitors a duty of reasonable care); Papadopoulos v. Target Corp., 457 Mass. 368, 379–80 (2010).
Mounsey v. Ellard, 363 Mass. 693, 707 (1.support_reasoning: Mounsey v. Ellard is the seminal Massachusetts case abolishing the common-law distinction between invitees and licensees and imposing on landowners a general duty of reasonable care to all lawful visitors. The quoted passage is from a concurrence and focuses on the treatment of trespassers, but the majority at 363 Mass. 707 expressly states that landowners owe a duty of reasonable care to lawful visitors. Thus, while the excerpt provided does not itself mention business invitees, the case as a whole supports the proposition that lawful entrants (including business invitees) are owed reasonable care.
Mounsey v. Ellard, 363 Mass. 693, 707 (1.relevant_excerpt: In abandoning the common law distinction between licensees and invitees, we hold that the proper test of a landowner's liability to a lawful visitor is whether in the management of his property he has acted as a reasonable man in view of the probability of injury to others. The status of the visitor as an invitee or licensee is no longer controlling.

Papadopoulos v. Target Corp., 457 Mass..proposition: At all times relevant, Plaintiff was a business invitee to whom Defendant owed a duty of reasonable care in the ownership, operation, inspection, maintenance, and control of the Premises, including the aisles, floors, and walking surfaces of the store.  See Mounsey v. Ellard, 363 Mass. 693, 707 (1973) (landowners owe lawful visitors a duty of reasonable care); Papadopoulos v. Target Corp., 457 Mass. 368, 379–80 (2010).
Papadopoulos v. Target Corp., 457 Mass..support_reasoning: Papadopoulos expressly reaffirms that, under Massachusetts premises liability law, a property owner owes ‘lawful visitors’ (which includes business invitees) a duty of reasonable care to maintain the property in a reasonably safe condition. The opinion repeatedly cites Mounsey v. Ellard for the rule that all lawful visitors are owed this reasonable-care duty and then applies that same duty to hazards from snow and ice in a retail parking lot. Although the case is focused on abolishing the natural/unnatural accumulation distinction, its reasoning squarely supports the general duty of reasonable care owed by Target, as a business property owner, to customers on its premises.
Papadopoulos v. Target Corp., 457 Mass..relevant_excerpt: “We now discard the distinction between natural and unnatural accumulations of snow and ice, which had constituted an exception to the general rule of premises liability that a property owner owes a duty to all lawful visitors to use reasonable care to maintain its property in a reasonably safe condition in view of all the circumstances. See Mounsey v. Ellard, 363 Mass. 693, 708 (1973).”

Sheehan v. Roche Bros. Supermarkets, Inc.raw_text: Sheehan v. Roche Bros. Supermarkets, Inc., 448 Mass. 780, 784–86 (2007)
Sheehan v. Roche Bros. Supermarkets, Inc.proposition: Alternatively, and/or in addition, the existence of cart tracks through the Spill demonstrates that the hazardous condition had existed for sufficient time that Defendant, in the exercise of reasonable care, should have discovered and remedied or warned of it, thereby establishing constructive notice.  See Sheehan v. Roche Bros. Supermarkets, Inc., 448 Mass. 780, 784–86 (2007) (mode of operation and notice principles); Deagle v. Great Atl. & Pac. Tea Co., 343 Mass. 263, 264–65 (1961).
Sheehan v. Roche Bros. Supermarkets, Inc.case_name: Sheehan v. Roche Bros. Supermarkets, Inc.
Sheehan v. Roche Bros. Supermarkets, Inc.support_reasoning: Sheehan abandons the traditional constructive-notice requirement based on the duration or appearance of a spill and instead adopts the mode‑of‑operation doctrine, under which proof of a foreseeable hazard inherent in the store’s self‑service operation substitutes for proof that the condition existed long enough to be discovered. The opinion does not state that cart tracks or similar indications of age are needed or sufficient to establish constructive notice; indeed, it expressly rejects the need to prove how long the substance was on the floor. Using Sheehan to support a traditional temporal-constructive‑notice argument mischaracterizes its holding.
Sheehan v. Roche Bros. Supermarkets, Inc.relevant_excerpt: “In sum, the adoption of the mode of operation approach will not modify the general rule governing premises liability requiring a plaintiff to prove that an owner had either actual or constructive notice of an unsafe condition on the premises. However, if a plaintiff proves that an unsafe condition on an owner’s premises exists that was reasonably foreseeable, resulting from an owner’s self-service business or mode of operation, and the plaintiff slips as a result of the unsafe condition, the plaintiff will satisfy the notice requirement…. It is not always necessary for liability that the produce have been on the floor long enough for the storekeeper to have had a reasonable opportunity to have seen and removed it.”

Deagle v. Great Atl. & Pac. Tea Co., 343.raw_text: Deagle v. Great Atl. & Pac. Tea Co., 343 Mass. 263, 264–65 (1961)
Deagle v. Great Atl. & Pac. Tea Co., 343.proposition: Alternatively, and/or in addition, the existence of cart tracks through the Spill demonstrates that the hazardous condition had existed for sufficient time that Defendant, in the exercise of reasonable care, should have discovered and remedied or warned of it, thereby establishing constructive notice.  See Sheehan v. Roche Bros. Supermarkets, Inc., 448 Mass. 780, 784–86 (2007) (mode of operation and notice principles); Deagle v. Great Atl. & Pac. Tea Co., 343 Mass. 263, 264–65 (1961).
Deagle v. Great Atl. & Pac. Tea Co., 343.case_name: Deagle v. Great Atlantic & Pacific Tea Co.
Deagle v. Great Atl. & Pac. Tea Co., 343.support_reasoning: The proposition asserts that evidence such as cart tracks or similar indicia (here, the spread of a spill) can establish that a hazardous condition existed long enough to give constructive notice. Deagle does the opposite: it holds that the plaintiff failed to prove the oil had been on the floor long enough for discovery, expressly finding that the large blotch of oil and surrounding circumstances did not allow an inference of sufficient duration. The case therefore undercuts, rather than supports, using such evidence alone to establish constructive notice.
Deagle v. Great Atl. & Pac. Tea Co., 343.relevant_excerpt: “In this state of the case it was incumbent upon the plaintiff to show that the oil had been on the floor for such a length of time that the defendant’s employees, in the exercise of reasonable care, should have been aware of its presence and taken steps to remove it or to warn the customers… The record discloses no description of the appearance of the oil which would in any way suggest that it had been on the floor for a sufficient length of time to have been discovered… The size of the ‘large blotch’ is not decisive for the oil could have covered an area so described within a few seconds or a few minutes.”

G.L. c. 231, \u00a7 6B.proposition: Plaintiff has suffered and will continue to suffer conscious pain and suffering, loss of enjoyment of life, inconvenience, and other non‑economic damages as a direct and proximate result of Defendant’s negligence.  See G.L. c. 231, § 6B (interest in personal injury actions); doCanto v. Ametek, Inc., 367 Mass. 776, 781–82 (1975).

doCanto v. Ametek, Inc., 367 Mass. 776,.proposition: Plaintiff has suffered and will continue to suffer conscious pain and suffering, loss of enjoyment of life, inconvenience, and other non‑economic damages as a direct and proximate result of Defendant’s negligence.  See G.L. c. 231, § 6B (interest in personal injury actions); doCanto v. Ametek, Inc., 367 Mass. 776, 781–82 (1975).
doCanto v. Ametek, Inc., 367 Mass. 776,.support_reasoning: The proposition concerns the types of non‑economic damages recoverable in a personal injury action (conscious pain and suffering, loss of enjoyment of life, inconvenience, etc.) and cites doCanto as authority. While doCanto is a personal injury/products liability case and the court affirms a substantial damages award, the opinion does not articulate or analyze the specific categories of non‑economic damages listed in the proposition, nor does it discuss G.L. c. 231, § 6B. The damages discussion is about excessiveness and lists functional loss, inability to work, pain and suffering, disfigurement, and future needs, not a doctrinal statement about the scope of recoverable non‑economic damages. Accordingly, the case does not meaningfully support the specific proposition for which it is cited.
doCanto v. Ametek, Inc., 367 Mass. 776,.relevant_excerpt: “In concluding that the judge committed no error of law, we consider Ezila’s age (twenty-nine) and weekly earnings ($140) at the time of the accident; the loss of ninety-five per cent of the function of her right hand (her dominant hand); her inability to perform many household tasks or to obtain employment; her pain and suffering, particularly while her hand was in the machine and while she was in the hospital where her fingers were amputated and skin grafts undertaken; her disfigurement, including scars from skin graft operations; her future need for artificial hands; and her continuing discomfort and embarrassment.”

Sarkisian v. Concept Restaurants, Inc.,.raw_text: Sarkisian v. Concept Restaurants, Inc., 471 Mass. 679, 684–86 (2015)
Sarkisian v. Concept Restaurants, Inc.,.proposition: At all relevant times, Defendant had a duty to properly train, supervise, and direct its employees to promptly identify, remedy, and/or warn of dangerous conditions on the floors of the Premises, especially in areas, such as the dairy aisle, where spills of liquids are reasonably foreseeable.  See Sheehan, 448 Mass. at 785–86 (mode of operation doctrine as to self-service supermarket operations); Sarkisian v. Concept Restaurants, Inc., 471 Mass. 679, 684–86 (2015).
Sarkisian v. Concept Restaurants, Inc.,.support_reasoning: The proposition asserts that the defendant had a duty to properly train, supervise, and direct employees to promptly identify, remedy, and/or warn of dangerous floor conditions, especially in foreseeable spill areas such as a dairy aisle, and cites Sarkisian as support. Sarkisian does recognize a duty of reasonable care under the mode-of-operation doctrine and even mentions that reasonable care in a nightclub might include sufficient staff to monitor and clean spills, but the opinion is about nightclub dance floors and the extension of the mode-of-operation approach beyond self-service stores—not about a general, explicit duty to train/supervise employees in supermarket aisles such as a dairy aisle. The case therefore provides only indirect, contextual support for a reasonable-care obligation, not the specific proposition as framed.
Sarkisian v. Concept Restaurants, Inc.,.relevant_excerpt: In the case of a nightclub operating with bars on the dance floor and permitting patrons to dance with their drinks, such reasonable care might include the employment of sufficient staff charged with monitoring and cleaning up spilled liquid on the dance floor at sufficient intervals, or the use of beverage containers on the dance floor that are less likely to spill liquid when jostled. See Restatement (Second) of Torts § 344 comment f (1965).

Oliveri v. Massachusetts Bay Transp. Aut.raw_text: Oliveri v. Massachusetts Bay Transp. Auth., 363 Mass. 165, 167–68 (1973)
Oliveri v. Massachusetts Bay Transp. Aut.proposition: Defendant’s conduct, as more fully described herein, constitutes negligence under Massachusetts law and was a direct and proximate cause of Plaintiff’s injuries and damages.  See Oliveri v. Massachusetts Bay Transp. Auth., 363 Mass. 165, 167–68 (1973); Poirier v. Plymouth, 374 Mass. 206, 212 (1978); Mullins v. Pine Manor College, 389 Mass. 47, 54–56 (1983).
Oliveri v. Massachusetts Bay Transp. Aut.case_name: Oliveri v. Massachusetts Bay Transportation Authority
Oliveri v. Massachusetts Bay Transp. Aut.support_reasoning: The proposition is a broad statement that the defendant’s described conduct constitutes negligence and was a proximate cause of plaintiff’s injuries under Massachusetts law. Oliveri does not address or affirm that a particular set of conduct constitutes negligence; instead, it holds that the evidence was insufficient to permit an inference of negligence and orders judgment for the defendant. While Oliveri recites general premises‑liability standards, its ultimate holding is that negligence was not established on the facts presented, so it does not support the proposition that the defendant’s conduct here was negligent and a proximate cause of the plaintiff’s injuries.
Oliveri v. Massachusetts Bay Transp. Aut.relevant_excerpt: “The obligation of one who controls business premises is to use due care to keep the premises provided for the use of its patrons in a reasonably safe condition, or at least to warn them of any dangers that might arise from such use, which are not likely to be known to them, and of which the defendant knows or ought to know… In summary, recovery has been denied to the plaintiff in the great majority of cases where he has attempted to establish the time element by circumstantial evidence… Exceptions sustained. Judgment for the defendant.”

Poirier v. Plymouth, 374 Mass. 206, 212.proposition: Defendant’s conduct, as more fully described herein, constitutes negligence under Massachusetts law and was a direct and proximate cause of Plaintiff’s injuries and damages.  See Oliveri v. Massachusetts Bay Transp. Auth., 363 Mass. 165, 167–68 (1973); Poirier v. Plymouth, 374 Mass. 206, 212 (1978); Mullins v. Pine Manor College, 389 Mass. 47, 54–56 (1983).
Poirier v. Plymouth, 374 Mass. 206, 212.support_reasoning: The cited Poirier excerpt is a concurring opinion that discusses the sufficiency of evidence for a premises-liability claim under a then‑existing ‘hidden defect’ rule and the court’s decision to abolish that rule. It does not articulate or apply a general standard of negligence or proximate cause under Massachusetts law, nor does it describe the elements of negligence in a way that supports the broad proposition that the defendant’s conduct constituted negligence and was a proximate cause of plaintiff’s injuries. The case is more about the premises-liability duty standard than about general negligence and causation principles.
Poirier v. Plymouth, 374 Mass. 206, 212.relevant_excerpt: “This action was tried by the parties and submitted to the jury on the plaintiff’s claim that he was injured by reason of a hidden or concealed defect on the defendant’s premises, of which defect the defendant was aware or should have been aware through the exercise of reasonable care. The jury returned a substantial verdict for the plaintiff. The defendant appealed, contending that there was insufficient evidence to support the verdict.… [T]his court is ordering that the verdict and judgment for the plaintiff be reinstated, holding that the evidence was sufficient to support the verdict.”

Mullins v. Pine Manor College, 389 Mass..raw_text: Mullins v. Pine Manor College, 389 Mass. 47, 54–56 (1983)
Mullins v. Pine Manor College, 389 Mass..proposition: Defendant’s conduct, as more fully described herein, constitutes negligence under Massachusetts law and was a direct and proximate cause of Plaintiff’s injuries and damages.  See Oliveri v. Massachusetts Bay Transp. Auth., 363 Mass. 165, 167–68 (1973); Poirier v. Plymouth, 374 Mass. 206, 212 (1978); Mullins v. Pine Manor College, 389 Mass. 47, 54–56 (1983).
Mullins v. Pine Manor College, 389 Mass..support_reasoning: The quoted text is from a dissent that expressly concludes the plaintiff failed to prove proximate cause and that defendants were entitled to judgment, which is the opposite of citing the case as support that a defendant’s conduct constituted negligence and was a proximate cause of injury. While Mullins as a whole is a leading Massachusetts negligence case recognizing a college’s duty and causation, this particular passage does not support that proposition and instead rejects proximate causation on these facts. Using this dissent as authority for the stated negligence-and-causation proposition is therefore inaccurate.
Mullins v. Pine Manor College, 389 Mass..relevant_excerpt: “In my opinion the plaintiff failed to introduce sufficient evidence to warrant a finding that action or inaction of the defendants was the proximate cause of her injury, and the defendants were entitled to directed verdicts and judgments in their favor.”

Bohenko v. Grzyb, 21 Mass. App. Ct. 961,.raw_text: Bohenko v. Grzyb, 21 Mass. App. Ct. 961, 962 (1986)
Bohenko v. Grzyb, 21 Mass. App. Ct. 961,.proposition: Under Massachusetts law, a possessor of land who invites members of the public onto the premises for business purposes owes those invitees a duty to exercise reasonable care to keep the premises in a reasonably safe condition and to protect them against foreseeable risks of harm.  See Mounsey, 363 Mass. at 707–08; Papadopoulos, 457 Mass. at 379–80; Bohenko v. Grzyb, 21 Mass. App. Ct. 961, 962 (1986).
Bohenko v. Grzyb, 21 Mass. App. Ct. 961,.support_reasoning: The case discusses a homeowner’s duty to social guests, not a possessor’s duty to business invitees or members of the public invited for business purposes. It cites Mounsey for the general standard that a homeowner must act reasonably for the safety of guests, but the factual context is purely social, not commercial, and the opinion does not articulate or apply a special rule concerning business‑purpose invitees. Thus it supports a general reasonable‑care duty to guests, not specifically the business‑invitee proposition stated.
Bohenko v. Grzyb, 21 Mass. App. Ct. 961,.relevant_excerpt: “As a homeowner, Grzyb’s duty was to act reasonably for the safety of his guests, no more and no less. Mounsey v. Ellard, 363 Mass. 693, 707-708 (1973). Polak v. Whitney, ante 349, 351 (1985). Grzyb was not obligated to take steps to avoid risks which he could reasonably assume would be open and obvious to his guests.”

Godbout v. Cousens, 396 Mass. 254, 257\u.proposition: Defendant either knew of the Spill (actual notice) through its employee’s observation of it prior to Plaintiff’s fall or, alternatively and/or in addition, the Spill existed for such a time and under such circumstances that Defendant, in the exercise of reasonable care, should have discovered its presence (constructive notice).  See Sheehan, 448 Mass. at 784–86; Deagle, 343 Mass. at 264–65; Godbout v. Cousens, 396 Mass. 254, 257–58 (1985).
Godbout v. Cousens, 396 Mass. 254, 257\u.support_reasoning: The proposition concerns premises liability and the concepts of actual and constructive notice of a spill, but Godbout v. Cousens is a defamation and intentional infliction of emotional distress case. The opinion does not address slip-and-fall law, storekeeper liability, or any standards for proving a defendant’s knowledge (actual or constructive) of a hazardous condition. Thus, it provides no authority for the notice rule described in the proposition and is mis-cited for that purpose.
Godbout v. Cousens, 396 Mass. 254, 257\u.relevant_excerpt: We now consider whether each of the defendants, in moving for summary judgment, met the initial burden to “show that there is no genuine issue as to any material fact and that [they are] entitled to a judgment as a matter of law.” Mass. R. Civ. P. 56 (c), 365 Mass. 824 (1974). … The substantive law of defamation determines which facts are material to the claims.

Jesionek v. Mass. Port Auth., 376 Mass..raw_text: Jesionek v. Mass. Port Auth., 376 Mass. 101, 105–06 (1978)
Jesionek v. Mass. Port Auth., 376 Mass..proposition: Defendant’s negligence, as described herein, was the direct and proximate cause of Plaintiff’s fall and the injuries and damages that followed.  See Mullins, 389 Mass. at 54–56; Jesionek v. Mass. Port Auth., 376 Mass. 101, 105–06 (1978).
Jesionek v. Mass. Port Auth., 376 Mass..support_reasoning: Jesionek directly addresses proximate cause where the defendant’s negligence (failure to secure the forklift) combined with a third party’s wrongful conduct caused plaintiff’s injury. The court holds that the negligent failure to secure the forklift could be found by the jury to be a culpable and direct cause of the plaintiff’s injury, rejecting the argument that the intoxicated seaman’s intervening act broke causation. This supports using Jesionek as authority that a defendant’s negligence can be the direct and proximate cause of a plaintiff’s injuries despite intervening third-party conduct.
Jesionek v. Mass. Port Auth., 376 Mass..relevant_excerpt: “The general rule is that ‘[t]he act of a third person, intervening and contributing a condition necessary to the injurious effect of the original negligence, will not excuse the first wrongdoer, if such act ought to have been foreseen. The original negligence still remains a culpable and direct cause of the injury.’ … It was thus reasonably foreseeable that the forklift… would be operated by unauthorized persons… Consequently, a jury could have found that the plaintiff’s injury was caused by a negligent act for which the authority was responsible.”

G.L. c. 231, \u00a7 85.proposition: As a further direct and proximate result of Defendant’s negligence, Plaintiff has suffered and continues to suffer pain and suffering, physical discomfort, loss of enjoyment of life, inconvenience, and other non‑economic damages, for which she is entitled to fair and reasonable compensation under Massachusetts law.  See G.L. c. 231, § 85 (comparative negligence framework); doCanto, 367 Mass. at 781–82; Santos v. Chrysler Corp., 430 Mass. 198, 205–06 (1999).

Santos v. Chrysler Corp., 430 Mass. 198,.proposition: As a further direct and proximate result of Defendant’s negligence, Plaintiff has suffered and continues to suffer pain and suffering, physical discomfort, loss of enjoyment of life, inconvenience, and other non‑economic damages, for which she is entitled to fair and reasonable compensation under Massachusetts law.  See G.L. c. 231, § 85 (comparative negligence framework); doCanto, 367 Mass. at 781–82; Santos v. Chrysler Corp., 430 Mass. 198, 205–06 (1999).
Santos v. Chrysler Corp., 430 Mass. 198,.support_reasoning: Santos deals with wrongful death, product liability, evidentiary issues, closing argument, comparative negligence in the wrongful‑death context, and nunc pro tunc judgment. It does not discuss the types of non‑economic damages recoverable in a personal injury action, such as pain and suffering, loss of enjoyment of life, or inconvenience, nor does it articulate a general rule that such damages are compensable under Massachusetts law. The opinion notes that the jury awarded compensatory damages including personal injuries and conscious pain and suffering, but it does not set out any legal standard or holding on entitlement to such non‑economic damages, so it does not meaningfully support the specific proposition cited.
Santos v. Chrysler Corp., 430 Mass. 198,.relevant_excerpt: “The jury awarded $12.8 million in compensatory damages for the wrongful deaths of the wife and children, the conscious pain and suffering of the wife, the wife’s lost future earnings, and the plaintiff’s personal injuries.” (430 Mass. at 201)

G.L. c. 231, \u00a7 6H.proposition: Plaintiff is entitled to recover pre‑ and post‑judgment interest on her damages at the statutory rate pursuant to G.L. c. 231, § 6B and § 6H.

G.L. c. 231, \u00a7 60.proposition: Plaintiff hereby demands a trial by jury on all issues so triable as of right pursuant to Mass. R. Civ. P. 38 and G.L. c. 231, § 60.
